compliance.notes: Minimum width of 900 mm between handrails, maximum gradient of 1 in 12, level area at top and bottom.

compliance.regulation: AODA Design of Public Spaces Standards
compliance.notes: Establishes minimum accessibility standards for outdoor public spaces and some indoor elements.
Includes requirements for elevators or other barrier-free access between storeys in most buildings.
Floors or walks in a barrier-free path of travel having a slope steeper than 1 in 20 shall be designed as ramps.

material_options.properties: High strength, excellent corrosion resistance, low maintenance, durable, metallic finish. Can last over 100 years with minimal upkeep.
Carbon steel base with a protective powder coating. Offers good corrosion resistance if coating is intact. Wide range of colors and textures available. Typically lasts 15-20 years.
Powder-coated steel with a textured finish for enhanced grip, improving safety in wet or high-traffic areas. Customizable colors.
Stainless steel with a brushed finish, offering a muted shine that reduces fingerprints and scratches, maintaining aesthetic appeal with enhanced durability.

maintenance.notes: Both stainless steel and powder-coated steel require regular cleaning with mild detergent and water. Avoid harsh chemicals on powder-coated steel.
Inspect powder-coated steel for damage to the coating. Touch up damaged areas promptly to prevent rust. Stainless Steel only check for corrosion or damage.
Powder-coated steel may require recoating every 10-15 years depending on environmental conditions.
Occasional passivation treatment can enhance the protective oxide layer on stainless steel, especially in harsh environments.

compliance.notes: Handrails shall be continuously graspable along their entire length with specific diameter or perimeter requirements. Height between 865 mm and 965 mm.
Handrails required on stairs and ramps as per Table 9.8.7.1. Stairs less than 1100 mm wide require at least one handrail.

compliance.regulation: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
compliance.notes: Handrails must provide a comfortable and secure grip. Extensions required at the top and bottom of stairs (300mm horizontal extension).
While not directly related to handrails, ensuring adequate lighting and contrast around stairwells and handrails aids visually impaired individuals.

cost_options.label: Surface Applied Anti-Slip Contrast Strip (Photoluminescent)
cost_options.notes: Materials: $13.70/linear foot (assuming 4 ft strip = $54.80), Labor: 2 hours @ $56.65/hr = $113.30. Total: ~$168.10. Prices can vary based on quantity and vendor. Installation includes surface preparation and adhesive application.

cost_options.label: Non Photoluminescent Surface Applied Anti-Slip Strips
cost_options.notes: Materials cost less than photoluminescent, ~$30 per 4ft strip, Labor: 2 hours @ $56.65/hr = $113.30. Total: ~$143.30. Includes surface cleaning and secure adhesion.

cost_options.label: Polymer Tactile Walking Surface Indicators - Glued Install
cost_options.notes: Materials: $2.64/sqft (depending on quantity), plus adhesive cost ~$20, Labor: 1 hour @ $56.65/hr = $56.65. Total: ~$79.29. Excludes surface prep.

material_options.properties: Cost-effective, can be wet set or applied later, INDOT approved, but less durable than steel/cast iron. Colors: Yellow, Colonial Red, Brick Red, Dark Grey, Black
Durable, lightweight, corrosion-resistant. Can be anodized or powder-coated for high contrast and slip resistance. Ideal for stair nosings.
Durable, flexible, polymer compounded, contemporary look and finish, suitable for high-traffic areas, tactile attention and direction indicators available.

Check for damage, loose strips, or wear and tear. Replace damaged sections immediately to prevent hazards.

compliance.regulation: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
compliance.notes: Requires tactile walking surface indicators in specific locations to assist visually impaired individuals. Must comply with contrast and dimension requirements.
Specifies requirements for tactile attention indicators, referencing ISO 23599 for dimensions and installation.

compliance.regulation: Canadian National Institute for the Blind (CNIB) Guidelines
compliance.notes: CNIB provides recommendations for accessibility standards, including the use and placement of tactile warning surfaces.
Assistive Products for Blind and Vision-Impaired Persons – Tactile Walking Surface Indicators. Defines key characteristics and dimensions

Addresses discrimination and requires organizations to accommodate people with disabilities.

maintenance.notes: Regular cleaning with mild detergent, touch-up paint as needed to address chips or wear every 1-2 years. Inspect for wear monthly.
Clean with a damp cloth and mild cleaner, replace strips as needed (typically 2-5 years depending on traffic). Inspect weekly.
Requires less frequent maintenance, typically cleaned with a damp mop. Inspect every 6 months and reapply coating after 5-10 years. Apply appropriate cleaning compounds for epoxy flooring.
Increase inspection and cleaning frequency for high-traffic stairs. Use entrance mats to reduce wear and tear.

compliance.regulation: AODA (Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act)
compliance.notes: Mandates accessibility improvements in Ontario, including tactile walking surface indicators and contrast markings. Compliance deadline was Jan 1, 2016.
Sets accessibility standards for new construction and renovations, including requirements for stair design and slip resistance, however does not offer guidance for signage.

compliance.regulation: CSA B651 (Accessible Design for the Built Environment)
compliance.notes: A national standard providing technical requirements for accessibility in buildings and site elements, including stairways, handrails, and tactile indicators.

compliance.regulation: CNIB (Canadian National Institute for the Blind) Guidelines
compliance.notes: CNIB provides recommendations for visual contrast and tactile warnings to improve accessibility for people with visual impairments.
